title: karren brady on women at work
story: I wanted to stop her right there and ask: “What on earth are you sorry about  Why don’t you know your worth “Why don’t you have ­confidence in the contribution you make ”It left me wondering why so many talented and competent women lack confidence at work to get the best out of their job. Why do they not get paid what they are worth to their company, and why are so many overlooked for promotion The sad fact is that for every £ men earn, women make just  pence.Just over one in ten women negotiated their starting salary, while more than half of all men haggle with their boss before they have even started work.When women do ask for more pay, they are  per cent less likely to get a raise. Andthey do receive a wage increase it will be  per cent less than men get.Sadly, it is common in business that women are often viewed as weak or unable to cope. And once we think about or start a family, we become toxic to employers.I receive hundreds of direct messages on social media from women asking: “How do I get a pay rise  How do I get noticed at work  How can I get promoted  How can I get on after maternity leave ”So now I am launching Get What You Want, a series of online masterclasses and podcasts covering everything from getting promoted to dealing with the word no, overcoming challenges, negotiating pay, writing a fantastic CV and nailing an interview.It will also cover baby-proofing careers, as well as becoming a super-mum after maternity leave.A lot of women have skills but just lack confidence. As women, we don’t shout about our wins enough for fear we will appear arrogant, even though men talk about them all the time.Here are some of my tips to winning at work.When people say: “I hate my job” I always ask: “Why are you telling me  I can’t do anything about it.”YOU have to do something. Sit down and work out what it is you don’t like about the position and set yourself a task of getting a new one.Be very dedicated and very professional and excel when you get to the interview.Many people don’t realise that when you are invited for an interview it is because they believe you can do the job.The secret is convincing them that you can do the job better than anyone .You should be able to talk about your specialist subject, which is yourself.People find it very dficult to list all the things they have done really well in a professional way to show good examples of why they can do the job.Opening a negotiation is all about knowing your worth.And knowing your value is really about your self-worth. They are totally linked.Write down all the things where you have made a big ­contribution, all the things that you have changed and made a dference, how you have added value. Put together testimonials to really back up what you have done.Then work out what more you want to do, because going above and beyond your job description is very important.Take out all the emotion, go in and lay out for your boss the facts of what you’ve contributed to the organisation.Sometimes people can be very passive. They say: “I’ll go along with what everyone  agrees with.”They want to avoid conflict. They don’t really think their opinion is as important as other people’s, so they are simply giving others a licence to ignore them.Learn to say no. Say: “I don’t really have the time butI can make the time I can do it for you.” Otherwise you become like a human sponge. Don’t let them take advantage.Employers take advantage of women’s lack of confidence, especially a mother ing from maternity leave. Many feel so grateful to have a job that they tend to put up with almost anything.Eleven per cent of new mothers report that they have been dismissed or made redundant where others in their workplace were not, or were treated so poorly they felt they had to leave.That means as many as , women are losing their jobs each year.Have a really clear plan of how you will manage at home and manage work. Get your partner to do his share  — and by that I mean half.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says may transition period
story: It is a trap, designed to keep us locked in to the EU racket.There’s nothing unreasonable about what Mrs May demanded yesterday — a backstop with a definite end date.Tusk, Barnier and Juncker will no doubt tell us it’s impossible.They will say “non” to any proposal we come up with, until the final seconds tick on the Brexit clock.The PM must hold her nerve. Because when it suits them, it’s amazing how many times the EU has shown a sudden flexibility.They are more than happy to break their sacred rules when it’s politically useful.They should be fining Italy for their illegal budget — but won’t, because it would stir a hornet’s nest of anti-EU feeling in a founder member.Brussels’ leaders do at least seem to understand we’re coming to the crunch.Unlike Leo Varadkar, the talkative Irish PM who is yet to see a microphone he didn’t like or miss an opportunity to undermine the UK.While our PM is giving statements in the Commons, this wannabe statesman is busy making jokes on Twitter about bailing Britain outBrexit goes badly.Ditch the jokes, Leo. There’ll be nothing funny for the Irish economyyour cack-handed comedy routine stops you trading with your closest neighbour.It’s getting serious. The PM knows that, and has done everything possible to get a deal.Now it’s Brussels’ turn.HAS the sun finally come out in Hundred Acre Wood Eeyore Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly considering a tax cut for struggling High Street businesses in next week’s Budget.About time too. Shops and pubs have been on the sharp end of business rate hikes, with many left at death’s door.A tax break would be a welcome sticking plaster, but in truth the rates system needs root and branch reform.The Chancellor must start on the second half of the High Street puzzle, too.Taxing the tech giants should be a Budget priority.MPs cannot be allowed to mark their own homework on bullying in Parliament.The evidence of a toxic culture in the House of Commons is compelling. The medieval process to deal with complaints simply cannot stand.The hypocrisy of MPs, who interfere in workplaces across the country on a daily basis, is staggering.The insufferable Speaker John Bercow has shown no appetite to give Commons staff the rights they deserve.Parliament must act.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keira knightley disney ban jane moore opinion
story: Sigh. Ms Knightley, who adds, “Rescue yourself,” clearly feels she is protecting daughter Edie by banning something that doesn’t concur with her own off-the-shelf, Poundland version of what feminism should be.But what she’s in danger of doing is wilfully nurturing a potential “snowflake” who, rather than develop the critical thinking skills that allow healthy debate, will simply stick their fingers in their ears and cry foul when they see or hear something that dfers from their own world view.Keira, tonight’s homework is to really readCinderella and analyse it.Look past the Disney-esque cute rodents, pretty frocks and glass slippers and instead dig a little deeper to ­appreciate the original’s narrative of how hope can turn unjust oppression into ­triumphant reward.Cinderella is a young woman who has not only suffered the loss of her loving father, but now faces a letime of abuse from an uncaring stepmother and her equally unpleasant daughters.But instead of sitting in the ashes ­waiting unquestioningly for whatever fate might have in store for her, she remains resolutely ­optimistic and decides to secretly defy her nemesis by gatecrashing a hot-ticket party to which she hasn’t been invited.Now that’s girl power.Ultimately, she “‘rescues” herself by proactively going to the ball where, instead of abuse, she experiences the redemptive qualities of love and kindness.They just happen to come in the form of a handsome prince.In the same week, Kristen Bell — who coincidentally voices Anna in the Disney film Frozen — found herself caught up in the slipstream of Keira’s PC virtue signalling after reportedly saying that Snow White gives young girls the wrong ­message about consent “because you cannot kiss someonethey’re sleeping”.Except Kristen’s comment was taken out of context and she’s got the balance right.Because what she actually said was that she reads the story with her two ­daughters, aged five and three, then asks them: “Don’t you think it’s weird that Snow White didn’t ask the old witch why she needed to eat the apple ” before starting up a conversation about the dos and don’ts of taking food from strangers.Or, “Don’t you think that it’s weird that the prince kisses Snow White without her permission ” to float an almost subliminal, age-appropriate understanding of what does and doesn’t constitute ­consent.Kristen isn’t banning tales of old, she’s using them to stimulate discussions.In other words, teaching her children the vital le skills of critical thinking — dictionary definition: “the objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment” — and being able to rationally debate that judgment with someone whose view might dfer from your own.Attempting to sanitise a child’s world by airbrushing history will hinder, not help them.Instead, wield history’s lessons as a tool to educate.Cinderella was of its time and now the Disney pendulum has seemingly swung the other way to depict a world where all the central characters are feisty, opinionated young women who power-kick their way through le.But how will Keira’s daughter know how far the depiction of Disney ­princesses has comeshe’s not allowed to see where they’ve been ONE morning last week, I spent a glorious couple of hours walking around Westminster Abbey.Buried or commemorated there are, among others, more than , great Britonsincluding Sir Isaac Newton, Jane Austen, Noel Coward, Charles Darwin, the Bronte sisters, Clement Attlee, Charles Dickens, David Livingstone, Stephen Hawking and, of course, the grave of the unknown warrior, buried on November ,  “in honour of the many multitudes who during the Great War of - gave the most that man can give . . . le itself.”My mother works at the Abbey as a “blue-gowner” – the volunteer guides there to answer any questions not covered by the electronic headsets – and, while showing us the ft by ft grave of poet Ben Jonson, who is the only person there to be buried upright, she was approached by a couple of earnest-looking women in their early twenties.Amid such a rich seam of history, rigorous intellect and achievement, what did they ask “Excuse me, where did David Beckham sit for the royal wedding ”THE number of stay-at-home dads has dropped to the lowest level in five years.Experts reckon it could be due to men “growing tired” of the tough job of raising kids.Proof,needed, might be the glassy-eyed expression of Bond actor Daniel Craig,  just six weeks after we Rachel Weisz gave birth to their daughter.He never looks this knackered when he’s jumping off buildings and dodging bullets.Stay-at-home parenthood can be isolating, sometimes dull, frequently thankless and relentlessly bloody exhausting. Only the strong survive it.THANKS to Ryanair’s ­astonishing failure to act when a passenger racially abused Windrush immigrant Delsie Gayle on one of its flights, the man will likely escape prosecution because of jurisdictional issues once a plane takes off from one country’s airspace to another.Instead, he is likely only to be banned from ever travelling on Ryanair again.Which, as plenty of the budget airline’s past ­customers might tell you, could equally be regarded as a blessing rather than a punishment.COMEDIAN Seann Walsh and his Strictly partner Katya Jones have survived the dreaded dance-off to, presumably, jive another day.Because, let’s face it, since that snog, the Strictly bosses are ­rapidly running out of drearily chaste dances to give them.Last weekend it was the unsexy Charleston, ­performed in equally unsexy “Where’s Wally” outfits that virtually screamed “nothing to see here”. Then this weekend it was a faintly ­ludicrous, undeniably platonic quickstep that saw them trotting around the floor like a couple of hyperactive show ponies.Assuming the sizzling Argentine tango is, er, strictly no-go, whatever next  A jive in burkas  A Viennese waltz in sackcloths Not least from Tom himself, perhaps, whose first we Mimi Rogers bemoaned the lack of intimacy in their union because, she claims, he wanted to be a monk and “thought he had to be celibate to maintain the purity of his instrument, but my instrument needed tuning, and we had to split.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: napoleon tribute act emmanuel macron sun says
story: On one side, Irish PM Leo Varadkar is more a comedian than he is a statesman, though it’s not a high bar to clear.On the other, Emmanuel Macron, a Napoleon tribute act whose stature is matched only by his collapsing poll ratings ­— and who is using tough talk on Brexit to distract from trouble at home.But Mini Manu’s threats ring hollow.Does he honestly think French businesses will thank himhe brings a huge chunk of the £billion-plus trade between our two countries to a halt Does he honestly think French consumers are so annoyed about our decision to leave that they’ll want lorries blocking their motorways and supermarket shelves empty But Macron’s desire to wreak havoc on the UK economy as a Brexit punishment betrays the Continent’s fear that an unleashed Britain would leave the EU in the dust.We have no desire for our Government to enter a trade war.If Britain goes without a deal — and there’s every chance — then we will show Europe what they’re missing with tax cuts and a red tape bonfire that will supercharge the economy.A sensible French leader would welcome a deal that works for both sides.Time for l’enfant terrible to grow up.GOOD luck to Sir James Dyson in Asia.His new Singapore plant will give his thriving British firm a foothold in the world’s fastest-growing car market.And it seems to have escaped the Remainers crowing that Brexit-backer Sir James has chosen to build abroad that — by their logic — we’d have to boot Nissan out of Sunderland.Brexit is about building a free trading Britain. That means being a part of a global economy. One in which the Japanese can build cars in the North East, American outfits can trade in the City and, yes, navy blue British passports can be made in France.Protectionism is a race to the bottom.BRITAIN now has the fourth lowest rate of home ownership in the EU.It is a damning indictment of decades of failed housing policy. Next week’s Budget is a chance for a radical sea change to ensure our property-owning democracy survives for generations.Don’t blow it, Chancellor.MPs shouldn’t have to march on Downing Street to end the witch-hunt against Northern Ireland veterans.But the PM and Cabinet must listen.The disgraceful pursuit must stop.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: grand designs concrete home
story: Deep-sea er, Adrian Corrigall and his we Megan spent  months building their house in Lewes, East Sussex, entirely out on concrete.The controversial development will appear on tonights episode of Channel s Grand Designs which sees host Kevin voice scepticism, comparing the property to a car park and electricity substation, adding that it doesnt look homely enough.Adrian, , and we Megan spent £, on the plot of land and budgeted to spend an additional £, on building the property.However, the couple ran into unexpected costs, adding £, to the final bill, forcing Adrian to take deep-sea ing jobs to bring in the cash, leaving Megan to manage the building of the house solo.She said: We have had an absolute nightmare, we’ve got credit cards and god knows what up to our eyeballs.She adds: We were pushed into this position where we couldn’t do anything, we had to go and get some money. So [Adrian] has gone and left me to it. It’s literally been the worst week of my le, it’s been awful.The couple stand by their creation, despite the financial hardship, which Adrian claims is inspired by concrete skate parks he used growing up as a BMX rider in Scotland.They use Swiss nano-concrete which uses cutting edge technology to micro-reinforce bits of glass fibre and shards of stainless steel to strengthen the concrete.Adrian said: Its a great big brutal concrete bunker. Building in concrete is a really simple way to build a house. You’re pouring concrete, you’re not messing around with bricks and mortar, and you’re not doing any of that.The property features four bedrooms, all with unfinished concrete walls, and a concrete swimming pool with a view of the surrounding countryside.Collected furniture inside the building gives it character, including a second hand university science classroom work station in the kitchen, complete with burns and stains uncleaned.Critical of the innovative design, which began being constructed in October , Kevin calls the building an unwelcoming fortress upon arrival.He then asks: Its pure and uncompromised… An aesthetic however, which is also going to be governed by the connotations of concrete, because underneath the questions of aesthetics lies a fundamental question: Could you live in a car park

title: teen asks how to burn cd
story: Before the days of streaming apps, music fans would assemble their favourite tracks onto CDs - a foreign concept to the younger generation these days.So when a teenager tweeted about the concept of CDs being burned it sparked a huge reaction.She wrote on Twitter: Maybe its just the generation Z in me but how did people burn CDs Like how did you just get a blank CD and put songs on it Thankfully one kind user explained the apparently ancient process.However most social media users took the opportunity to point out how old the tweet made them feel.One jokingly replied: All my hair turned grey reading this tweet.Another said: Part of me wants to explain how I used a blank cassette tape to record songs off the radio when I was a kid but I dont think Ill have time because theyve already lowered my casket into the hole and theyre shoveling dirt onto me at a truly frightening speed.A third user wrote: We would wait for a full moon and throw a blank CD into a giant bonfire and dance around it while chanting the titles of the songs we wanted on it.The final product would be sitting on top of the ashes after the flames went out.

title: these creepy pics prove halloween was much scarier 100 years ago
story: Around a century ago, young pranksters were slammed in newspaper reports for being reckless “miscreants” who kept police, ambulances and even wrecking crews running ragged as they terrorised neighbourhoods.In the decades before trick-or-treating became popular, mischief and pranks were the order of the day as children celebrated Halloween more than adults in the early s.For example in , “almost from the time darkness appeared youngsters had a good time, parading the streets in every conceivable costume and make-up and making the night hideous with horns and other noise-makers,” reported the Daily Press in Virginia.One small boy earned the ire of townsfolk for “pulling doorbells, dumping ash barrels, be-flouring pedestrians and making himself a terror and a nuisance to the community,” said The Times in .The kids antics – published by Mental Floss – make interesting reading, as a Nebraska newspaper noted in  that “Some Hallowe’en revellers tied a cow to each of the front door knobs of the high school, and put a buggy on the roof of the building.”In , the Ottumwa Semi-Weekly Courier in Iowa reported that a group of girls “dressed in sheets and pillowcases… went all over the town and soaped windows and automobiles.“We went to a house where there was a Hallowe’en party… and made all kinds of noises. A woman came out and we hid around the house. When she came back in we soaped all her windows. We all had a good time.”But the tide did turn for some kids, as The Bourbon News in Kentucky reported a Harrodsburg man “who anticipated the removal of his gates put molasses on them, and several nice young men had their clothes ruined.”An investigation was launched in  when an Evangelical church was “desecrated on Halloween” when “miscreants placed a beer keg on the altar”.A more terrying prank, though, involved a “shapely tailor’s dummy, taken by jokesters from a dressmaking establishment” and used to imitate a corpse in Oklahoma.The Morning Tulsa Daily World reported in  that the mannequin was so lelike that “police, an ambulance and a wrecking crew were hurriedly summoned when a terried car crew found the ‘body’ of a woman jammed beneath the trucks of their car on reaching the barns.“Police and the wrecking crew raised the car and hauled out the ‘body’. It was a shapely tailor’s dummy.”It wasn’t until the s and s that trick-or-treating became more commonplace.American author Lesley Bannatyne, who has written five books on Halloween, said the“destructive element of Halloween was distasteful to Victorians”.Halloween celebrations during the early s saw a leap from the late s when, “children’s magazines printed pretty pictures of fairies and witches and ladies’ periodicals became concerned with how a Halloween party was given”, Bannatyne explains.While kids were allowed to run wild and be a menace on the streets, it was a dferent situation for hostesses, who by the turn of the century were leaving jack-o’-lanterns on doorsteps.“As Victorian ladies were expected to be handy with crafts, most Halloween party invitations were handmade in the shape of Halloween symbols and featured a rhyming verse,” Bannatyne added.Also, at this time Halloween parties were “often used for matchmaking” with plenty of opportunity for romance to blossom.The author said: “Halloween celebrations in the Victorian age seem to be made of one part romantic inspiration, one part reconstructed history, and one part Victorian marketing.“Halloween stories became almost operatic with regard to passion, and less concerned with actual ghosts.”When it came to throwing parties, Bannatyne said: “A highly dramatic entrance was a must.The party-giver’s house was completely dark, lit only with jack-o’-lanterns, fireplaces or long snakes made of tin and fastened above a light, whose heat made the serpent writhe.“Dark-robed figures led guests to the cellar, the kitchen or some other darkened room… some hostesses greeted their guests with an old elbow glove filled with sawdust.”Others, though, used decorations such as tall hanging ghosts or monstrous cobwebs made of yarn.Some hostesses served Scottish scones and party guests were also offered the likes of half-pumpkins filled with apples, grapes and pears, or chicken salad in hollowed-out turnips.A dangerous party game in Victorian parlours involved people jumping over a candle flame, “with full dress trains and tight, hitched-up pants”.They would hold storytelling contests around the fire, where guests would each take a “twig and set it burning, at the same time telling an impromptu ghost story.“Popular theme parties appeared in the early s, centred on black cats or a haunted house, for example turning cellars into caverns.Halloween disguises were “still a novelty at adult parties as late as  they gained popularity during the first decades of the th century,” she added.In the early s as new traditions emerged, such as town-wide Halloween parades, the American press labelled the occasion as the “Halloween problem”.Papers reported kids setting off fire alarms, throwing bricks through shop windows and painting obscenities: They begged for money or sweets and threatened vandalismthey didn’t receive them.Unamused adults fought back, however, as early th century newspapers published stories on homeowners firing “buckshot at pranksters who were only  or  years old” in America.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fisherman surrounded crocodiles night
story: Arash Tayebbi was fishing in a notoriously croc-infested waterway in Australia when up to  of the man-eating reptiles hemmed him in on both sides.Footage shows the crocodileseyes glowing eerily as Arash aimed his flashlight back and forth on the banks of Shady Camp billabong.But bizarrely, Arash says he found his encounter relaxing.He said: It was so dark I could only see them with the flashlight.There was loads of them on both sides of the barrage, up to .But Im comfortable with that spot and nature generally relaxes me.If you love fishing you have to accept the risks, especially with how remote the Top End is.Shady Camp is one of the most densely populated crocodile destinations in the world and its been the site of a number of fatal attacks involving fisherman.In , -year-old Bill Scott was taken from his boat by a .mcrocodile while emptying a bucket over the side of his boat.Arash said that although he has nearly been attacked by crocs at the same spot, it wont stop him from fishing there in the future.He explained:Ive nearly been attacked by crocodiles in that spot three times before at night.Every time I kept a distance from the bank of three metres. As long as you dont have kids or pets with you, and you keep a keen eye, that should be enough to get away.Im used to that place and feel connected to all the animals there.

title: theresa may supporters brexit love in
story: The PM was forced to rip up her schedule to address all ministers and backbenchers at a tense meeting of the party’s  Committee.Furious Brexiteers had billed the showdown as a final reckoning with her, with one even suggesting she should “bring her own noose”.But in what MPs dubbed a carefully coordinated operation by her whips, Mrs May was greeted with cheers and desk banging which continued through out the -minute meeting.And No was confident that Mrs May had done enough to see off the threat of a no confidence vote in her this week.One Brexiteer MP, Michael Fabricant insisted the PM had won the room over, emerging to say: “It’s not Daniella in the Lion’s Den, it’s a petting zoo in there.“It was a love in. Everybody was saying we need unity.”The PM spelled out to the room why she was pursuing a softer Brexit vision, warning that the referendum decision to leave the EU could have “consequences”.One MP told The Sun: “She said that we will be able to look voters in the eye and say we have honoured our commitment to uphold the referendum.“But she also said it’s the job of government to make sure that whatever Brexit we end up with, we will protect the economy from the cosequences.”Home Secretary Sajid Javid told The Sun that it was a “solid performance” that “will put to bed once and for all that she is the person to lead us”.But other Tory MPs branded the meeting “totally stage managed” with Whips planted to bang on the doors to make the applause from inside seem louder.One Leave-backing MP told The Sun that Mrs May’s pitch “wasn’t great”, adding: “She hasn’t won me over”.Some of the PM’s biggest critics, including former Tory leader IDS, stayed away altogether.Another senior Brexiteer backbencher said: “It was your standard  meeting, tightly controlled and designed for one thing - to give the leader a good show”.Most of the questions aimed at the PM were supportive, with MPs urging loyalty.But Brexit backer Andrew Bridgen tackled Mrs May directly on her handling of the negotiations on what concessions she had won from Brussels.As the PM began to reel off what she saw as wins on Citizens Rights, the ECJ and the transition period, MPs broke into applause in a bid to shore her up against her fiercest critics.Brexiteer Nadine Dorries also repeated her call for a change of leader after leaving the room.More Cabinet isions emerged yesterday when it emerged that Energy minister Claire Perry had made a thinly veiled dig at Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt for taking a position on Brexit just to further his leadership hopes.Ms Perry’s attack came during a meeting of the PM’s top table in No on Tuesday.Last night Theresa May was urged to back a FIVE-DAY debate on her final Brexit deal – where MPs would have the ability to consider alternatives before voting on the PM’s agreement.Former Tory Attorney General Dominic Grieve said this would allow MPs to see the scale of Commons support for other options such as a Norway-style deal before the crunch vote.Trying to avoid debate on alternatives would “be both wrong, and,I may add, I think it would be a very big mistake”.Today Environment Secretary Michael Gove will introduce the Fisheries Bill in Parliament – promising Britain is on the way to “taking back control of our waters”.The legislation will end the automatic right of EU vessels to fish in UK waters and proposing powers to ensure the UK can set its own fishing quotas.An Ipsos MORI poll yesterday revealed growing pessimism amongst the British public on Mrs May’s chances of getting a good deal.We are wary of it lasting a day beyond . title: prince harry meghan markle tonga fiji latest
story: The Duchess wowed in green in Fiji and stunned in red after a mid-air outfit change before meeting royalty in the Pacic island nation this morning.She looked amazing in her Self Portrait dress, blue stilettos and black clutch bag - but eagle eyed fans noticed a stray tag hanging from the hem.The Duke and Duchess took a -minute flight to Tonga, on day ten of their South Pacic tour, and she made sure her wardrobe matched the colour of the national flag.The couple landed at Fuaamotu Airport in the countrys capital and were welcomed by Princess Angelika Latufuipeka and dancers in grass skirts.Meghan, who was forced to cut duties short after a security scare yesterday, looked refreshed after a night along with Harry on a private luxury island.The royal couple then walked the red carpet, accompanied by traditional entertainment from Pelehake villagers.Airport staff met them holding a sign saying Welcome Harry and Meghan, and waving Union Jacks.They were then escorted off to Consular House for a private audience with King Tupou VI and Queen Nanasipauu.They will then attend an official reception and dinner, featuring traditional entertainment.Schoolchildren had been given the day off and lined the streets from the airport to the capital of Nukualofa, waving flags and cheering as the convoy made the -minute journey.The royal pair first appeared at Fijis Nadi Airport this morning, where they unveiled a statue of SAS hero Sgt Talaiasi Labalaba.The super-solder died in battle after holding off  rebels on his own.Meghan looked classy in a green £, Jason Wu dress, which showed off her growing baby bump, and tall black heels.Harry looked dapper in a grey suit and wore military medals as he honoured Sgt Talaiasi, who was killed in the Battle of Mirbat in .He was stationed in Oman with eight SAS soldiers on a secret assignment, codenamed Operation Jaguar.When their hideout was ambushed, he sprinted - title: jamal khashoggi turkish spies knew
story: NewsJamal Khashoggi: Turkish spies listened in as journalist was butcheredEXCLUSIVE: Intelligence chiefs launched a huge surveillance operation to track the hit squad sent by RiyadhShareCommentsByChris HughesDefence and Security Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsJournalist Jamal Khashoggi arriving at the Saudi Arabian consulate in Istanbul on October  "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTurkish spies knew Saudi Arabia was plotting against Jamal Khashoggi, weeks before he was killed, sources have told the Daily Mirror. Intelligence chiefs launched a huge surveillance operation to track the hit squad sent by Riyadh. The Saudi consulate in Istanbul was bugged, and spies listened in as Mr Khashoggi was killed and dismembered, it is claimed. But sources say Turkey had believed the Saudi operatives were planning to kidnap Mr Khashoggi, not execute him at the consulate. Intelligence services learned the journalist was allegedly targeted under the orders of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, in revenge for opposing his reign.  The “Saudi ” hit squad included a key member of his entourage. A senior security source said: “Turkey launched a large-scale surveillance operation. Many in the intelligence community believe the consul was bugged, and this Saudi team was followed. “The uncomfortable truth may emerge one day that the hit team was listened to live as they killed Khashoggi, but [Turkey] was powerless to do anything about it.” Sources said authorities would have had little time to respond.  The Mirror revealed recently that Western intelligence agencies knew of Saudi plans to kidnap dissidents, echoing jihadi renditions by the US, Israel and Russia. The source said: “Turkey was expecting a rendition attempt, which they could interdict, rescuing Khashoggi. Instead, they witnessed a murder and [used] it as leverage against the Saudis.” Turkey claims it has taped proof of the murder. Thanks to its major intelligence operation, it is thought it has further information on Mr Khashoggi’s killing, which it is not admitting to.  Mr Khashoggi was murdered in the consulate on October . Afterwards, one of his suspected killers left the building in his clothes to make it appear he was still alive. The search for Mr Khashoggi’s remains continued today in the consulate garden, close to where some of his body is believed to have already been found.  Today, bin Salman described the killing as a “heinous crime that cannot be justied”. Speaking at an international conference in Riyadh, he said: “The incident is very painful. Justice in the end will appear.”

story: NewsSingle mums reveal true horror of Universal Credit in damning testimony to ParliamentWomen told how the benefit left them with £, bills, fines and a £-a-day survival rate. Heres what they told MPs - and why it mattersShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video mums-descend-parliament-tell-how-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave group of single mums today revealed the true chaos of Universal Credit in damning testimony to Parliament. Women told how the Tories six-in-one benefit, designed to be a better system that makes work pay, left them with pound, childcare bills, late payment fines and even being kicked out of nursery. One mum said she was forced to turn down her dream job because it would have left her with just pound a day for food, bills, nappies and petrol. Thuto Mali, mum to a two-year-old boy, confessed: We were at the food bank last Christmas because it got that bad. It’s not that I don’t want to work - it’s just that work doesnt pay. Heres what they told MPs - and why it matters.  The four women gave evidence to the Work and Pensions Committee as UC - already rolled out to .million people, and due to hit million by December  - pushes the poor to rent arrears and food banks. Theresa May is facing huge pressure to pump more money into the benefit, which has been bundled up with billions in welfare cuts since it launched in . So far campaigners have focused on this and other problems with the benefit, like the five-week wait for payment. But today the single mums talked about a dferent side to the story - how Universal Credit affects childcare. Working parents on UC can claim back % of their nursery fees. Yet they have to pay up-front first, and claim the money back later. The mum fined and saddled with a pound, bill  The policy saddled mum-of-two Vikki Waterman with a pound, bill which she had to wait five weeks to be paid back. The -year-old was also fined pound by her nursery because a late benefit payment meant she was two days behind paying for childcare. She told MPs: We dont want to sit at home when we didnt plan to be single parents. We shouldnt be penalised for that. That is not what we are here for. We want to be able to go to work and to provide for our own families, and at the minute it seems asthere is a roadblock everywhere we turn.  Hairdresser and mum-of-three Gaynor Rowles, from Heywood, Greater Manchester, was forced to pay up-front costs for her three-year-old twins. It’s pound per week. Where do I find that money from ” she said. Describing how she was just pound. a week better off in work, I’ve changed as a person. I’m not my normal happy self. Its quite sad really. Theres more people out there who are worse off than me. Ive got good family, good friends and good support. The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. Thuto Mali revealed her little boy was even suspended from nursery. “I was paying, I think, half or three quarters of it and his dad was supposed to pay the other - it didn’t quite happen, she said. So I got whacked with an pound bill. She said she was forced to turn down a job with a pound, salary because after paying pound, a month for a full-time nursery spot for her son she would be left with pound a month to cover bills. Thats effectively pound a day, she said. Work didnt pay for us.  Nail technician Lucy Collins, from Manchester, told MPs she left her job in the police because she couldnt fit shts around her kids, aged  and . Only then did she discover the problems of being on Universal Credit. You just get passed from pillar to post, she said. It’s so complex.  Astonishingly, MPs heard the system is more lenient on well-off parents than it is on people claiming benefits. People on Universal Credit must submit receipts and invoices on an online journal to ensure they get the money back. Dalia Ben-Galim, policy director at the charity Gingerbread, told MPs: Theres a very dferent burden of proof on more middle-class parents. You don’t need to submit receipts - you need to have a registered childcare provider.  The moneys in your account and you, as a parent, are able to transfer that directly. I think that is ideological - it’s an active decision that has been made. Shocked Tory MP Heidi Allen branded the double standard terrible. Committee chairman Frank Field added the whole system is middle-class management of money. It doesn’t take into accountyou have a daily wage or a weekly wage. What the DWP says  A Department for Work and Pensions spokeswoman said: We are doing more than ever before to support parents with the cost of childcare and by - we will be spending around a record pound billion on childcare support. Under Universal Credit, working parents can claim back up to % of eligible childcare costs, compared to % of costs covered under the previous legacy system. This is the highest level of support ever. Andsomeone has accepted an offer of paid work, they are eligible to be paid these costs for the month prior to starting work. This generous provision has been widely welcomed by stakeholders and is available in addition to an entitlement of up to  hours of free childcare.

She had only been married  hours when she was was told she had pancreatic cancer - and had just months left to live. The only symptom she had experienced before the diagnosis was stomach pains and she was offered an ultrasound examination to be safe. Julie, who works as an Emergency Care Assistant, met Ian in the ambulance service and has helped hundreds of patients over the years. Many of them have already contributed to a fundraising page set up to help her.  She has been undergoing chemotherapy but due to the position of the tumor an operation has been deemed too risky. Julie, of Hayle, Cornwall, said she almost cancelled the ultra-sound operation as she felt completely fine. She added: After the ultrasound I got a call to say they had found a shadow. I wasnt worried. I didnt think it would be anything because I felt so good. Then, two days after my wedding, I got the diagnosis - it was pancreatic cancer. The first thing that went through my mind was that I would never get to celebrate my first wedding anniversary with Ian. It was hard. I thought I wouldnt be around for Christmases or my grandchildrens birthdays. So I actually went out and bought four years worth of cards for them all, in case I wasnt around. Every  minutes someone in the UK is diagnosed with a blood cancer, according to the non-profit advocacy group DKMS. This may be leukaemia, lymphoma or myeloma. Blood cancer is the third most common cause of cancer death in the UK. However, only one in three people with it - and in need of a transplant - will find a matching blood stem cell donor within their own family. Two in three need to look outside of this.Around  per cent of all donations are made through a method called peripheral blood stem cell . This is where blood is taken from one of the donor’s arms and a machine extracts the blood stem cells from it.The donor’s blood is then ed to them through their other arm. The outpatient procedure is typically completed in four to six hours. In  per cent of cases, donations are made through bone marrow collection. This is done while under general anaesthetic. Now she is hoping that, by sharing her story so that others can be more aware, it could help more people catch the illness early and recognise symptoms. She added: They havent given me a set prognosis but the le expectancy for people with inoperable pancreatic cancer isnt long at all its about nine months.  Treliske said that due to where the tumour is, it is inoperable. So I started emailing every expert and professor I could find as I dont feel like I should be written off. I have been up to the Royal Free Hospital in London and spoken to a professor up there who has agreed to operate providing the tumour shrinks. I have contacted every clinical trial going. With Julie having to take time off work, covering the costs of travel to London, fees for any trials she gets accepted for and having also been given notice to leave her home, financial strains have taken their toll. story: NewsWhy Meghan Markles baby bump appears so much bigger at nightPeople were surprised by how much her baby bump had grown when she appeared at a state dinner on the islandShareCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video meghan-markle-stuns-blue-dress-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are finding even more eyes on them than usual lately after they announced their baby news on the day they landed in Australia for a -day tour of Commonwealth countries.The couple have been out and about meeting the public in Australia and Fiji so far on their diary-busting trip, which has a whopping  official engagements. But what Meghan might be finding a bit odd is that all eyes are now on her stomach, which the mum-to-be has been sweetly cradling while at events. And people were surprised when her bump seemed to miraculously grow over the course of a day when the Duke and Duchess touched down in Fiji. Meghan, who is around four months pregnant, was seen wearing an elegant white dress to land on the island, and her bump wasnt that visible.  But when she changed into a stunning blue cape gown for a state dinner that evening, social media users went wild with confusion.  Emily Andrews, the Suns royal correspondent who is following the couple on the tour, said on the night of the state dinner: I also note that Meghan’s baby bump is getting bigger by the day! I swear it was not this big last week! I think it’s the clinging nature of the dress but she’s sure looking swell! Although the fact the dress is clinging to her - and the fact she is holding her bump - might make it appear larger, one doula thinks it might be down to a biological factor. Susanna Birch told Trimester Talk: At night time, your abdominal muscles are tired from holding your bump [and they] loosen as they grow more tired, which allows your bump to sit out further and appear larger.An obstetrician also told Mamamia that it could be down to bloating from having eaten over the course of the day.But another possible cause of womens bumps being bigger at night is the hormone progesterone, which is released from the placenta. The hormone is thought to be an evolutionary advantage for pregnant women in days when there was not as much food available - so food digestion is slowed and they absorb all possible nutrients to pass on to their unborn baby. Dr Sgroi also believes Meghans bump is likely to look even bigger by the end of the tour - which is less than a week away - given it is thought she is around four months pregnant.  After about  weeks onwards, this uterus which is predominantly in the pelvis now starts to move to the tummy or the abdomen, and thats when you start to show more and more, he told Mamamia. A source confirmed to the Mirror that William was flying the helicopter himself.The Duke was once an RAF search and rescue pilot in the military and then went on to get his civilian pilots licence before he joined the East Anglian Air Ambulance.  One said: Yes HE does this ... lol ... once he landed the helicopter at kates parents residence for a quick pop in. Others have rejoiced at the fact he seems to be carrying a bag for Louis nappies and other belongings. Another said: All I could see is that Louis seems to have on a pale blue sweater and blonde hair! Maybe he is wearing one like George had with Louis on it. Kate dazzled in Princess Dianas favourite tiara last night at the state dinner in Buckingham Palace - although her choice of gown has been questioned, with one person calling it her worst ever dress . The Duchess also wore the Royal Family Order for the second time, made of glass rather than ivory.  She attended the event with Prince William, who walked with Prime Minister Theresa May in the procession before dinner. Meanwhile, Louis uncle Harry is still on his royal tour of Commonwealth countries with new we Meghan Markle.

title: queen kate middleton wore tiaras
story: NewsWhy the Queen and Kate Middleton wore tiaras to state dinners but Meghan Markle didntThis is what determines whether royal women wear tiaras at formal events or notShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  OCT News "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailState dinners are some of the rare occasions when royal women are allowed to wear fancy tiaras from the royal family’s collection. Given that the Queen wore one at the Fijian state banquet on her tour their in , royal fans speculated that this would be wear Meghan Markle made her tiara-debut. However, Meghan went for a more low-key look and did not wear any jewels on her head at the event. She looked stunning in a floor- blue gown and topped off her look with a dazzling pair of earrings.  Meanwhile, Kate Middleton wore a tiara last night at the Dutch state banquet. It was a beautul diamond-encrusted tiara Kate has worn several times before, the Cambridge Lovers Knot tiara, which once belonged to Princess Diana. So, why did the Queen and Kate wear tiaras at state dinners but Meghan didnt  It turns out that royal protocol regarding tiaras actually has nothing to do with the Duchesses royal ranks - so its not because Kate is closer to the crown.  The choice of whether or not to wear a tiara is determined by the dress code of the event, as well as personal preference. In this case, the event was evidently black tie - so a tiara is not necessary. Another important factor is that state dinners are less formal than state banquets, which could have been one of Meghans reasons for going tiara-free. She may also have been advised not to travel with the expensive jewellery.A royal source told Hello magazine that there was no expectation for the Duchess to wear a tiara at the event, but said she was suitably attired for a state occasion.

title: socialite accuses businessman centre metoo
story: NewsSocialite accuses businessman at centre of #MeToo gagging order row of sexual assaultThe anonymous businessman won a high court injunction preventing the Dailyfrom reporting allegations of sexual assault against himShareByNatalie EvansUS Editor Brian FarmerSam Blewett:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe woman accuses the businessman at the centre of the gagging order row of sexual assault "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman claims she was sexually assaulted by an anonymous businessman who won a high court injunction preventing a national newspaper from reporting #MeToo allegations against him. The unnamed woman, described as a well-known socialite by the newspaper, said the man put his hand up her skirt during the alleged incident at a party in the late noughties. Writing anonymously in Thursdays Daily , she said: He loved that I was scared. It comes after thelost the latest round of a free speech fight with the company boss accused of discreditable conduct. Three Court of Appeal judges barred the newspaper from publishing confidential information after analysing rival arguments at a hearing in London. The paper wants to reveal what it calls alleged sexual harassment and racial abuse of staff, who have been prevented from discussing their claims by non-disclosure agreements .  The woman is reportedly not among staff who are said to have signed NDAs. She wrote: The businessman, now chatting to my boyfriend, drops his hand to my thigh and slides it up beneath my dress to cup my rear. There it sits, proprietorially but also mockingly - you cant see what Im doing to your girlfriend right in front of your eyes ...One MP has vowed to help fight the gagging order. Jess Phillips, Labour MP for Birmingham Yardley, urged victims to contact her, adding that she was done with these rich men using our laws to hide you away. Speaking totoday, she said: I dont know his name so I cannot name him. But she added: I plan to find out as much as I can about the case, hope that victims would seek me outI can offer some sort of cover, and make sure that, whatever I do, I dont damage them.  Under Parliamentary privilege, Phillips would have legal immunity against civil or criminal liability for actions done or statements made in the course of their legislative duties - for example, naming the businessman in the House of Commons. The unnamed businessman, a senior executive in a company group, plus managers at two companies in the group, took legal action in a bid to stop thepublishing a story. A High Court judge had, in August, refused to gag the newspaper. But the executive and managers at the two companies mounted a challenge and three appeal judges have overturned Mr Justice Haddon-Caves decision. Sir Terence Etherton, Lord Justice Underhill and Lord Justice Henderson have outlined their decision in a ruling. They said five employees of companies in the group had made allegations of discreditable conduct by the executive. In all five cases complaints had been compromised by settlement agreements under which substantial payments were made to the employees who had complained. Both sides had undertaken to keep confidential the subject matter of complaints. The three judges had overseen a Court of Appeal hearing in September and published a ruling on Tuesday. The three appeal judges have not named anyone involved, apart from the newspaper. They named the claimant executive and companies as ABC  others.

title: uk weather forecast winter way
story: NewsUK weather forecast: Winter on the way as Brits wake up to frost, ice and even snowThe last of the mild weather is behind us as temperatures take a tumble today with Saturday expected to be the coldest dayShareCommentsByMirror:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video watch-forecast-week-ahead-temperatures-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWinter is certainly on the way with overnight frosts and ice in places - and even snow on hills in Scotland, Northern Ireland and possibly the north of England. A marked change is expected this weekend from the current mild weather as the UK leaves British Summer Time. The Met Office tweeted: The clocks will be going back this weekend, but so are the temperatures!! Met Office chief meteorologist Laura Paterson said: It will feel very cold this weekend, with strong winds bringing heavy showers to many parts. Northern-facing coastal areas will see the most frequent showers, whilst where will see more in the way of sunshine. These showers could contain hail and turn to snow on the high ground, mainly Scotland, Northern Ireland and perhaps northern England.  Met Office meteorologist John West described it as a real change in feel from the rather mild weather due to high pressure in the UK and replaced by a strong northerly flow from the Arctic. Wednesday is the last of the warmer days, with temperatures taking a tumble from tomorrow!! according to the Met Office.  Temperatures of C in Aberdeen and C in Southampton on Wednesday will respectively fall to C and C on Thursday, C and C on Friday and C and C on Saturday. Mr West said: While the thermometers will be maxing out at about C it will feel colder in that strong northerly wind.  The dference will be felt in daytime temperatures, with westerly winds on Wednesday compared to northerly winds on Saturday. It looks like Saturday will be the coldest day, with temperatures recovering slightly for Sunday and showers becoming more confined to eastern areas. Stein Connelly, of Transport Scotland, said: Snow, sleet and ice look set to move into parts of Scotland at the end of this week, particularly over higher routes. Our operating companies have already started their winter services and will closely monitor the trunk road network, providing appropriate treatments where necessary. As always, we encourage motorists to plan their journeys ahead of time, follow police travel advice and drive to the conditions.  Three-day UK weather forecastToday: It will be a fine start with sunny spells for many southern and eastern areas, although skies will become cloudy for most by midday. There will be rain for most of Scotland, though it will be heaviest in the north-west. It will be drier for a time in southern Scotland. Rather breezy in the north Tonight: It will be a wet and breezy start for northern areas. However, skies will gradually clear with clear spells and wintry showers later. Becoming much colder. In the south, it will start dry and overcast, although it will become damp later in the night towards dawn. Moderate north-westerly winds UK Outlook: It will become much colder on Friday and Saturday than recent days with sunny spells and showers. The showers will be most frequent for northern coasts, although will affect western coasts on Friday and eastern coasts on Saturday. Mostly dry and sunny for central and southern areas. Brisk winds

story: NewsAmerican big game hunter sparks fury in Britain after posing with slain animals on Scottish huntLarysa Switlyk posted a series of images on her social media pages showing off the “medals” from her hunts on the island of IslayShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsLarysa Switlyk posing with an animal during her visit to Scotland "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn American big game hunter has sparked fury in Britain after posing with slain goats, sheep and stags on a Scottish hunt. Larysa Switlyk posted a series of images on her social media pages showing off the “medals” from her hunts on the island of Islay. The -year-old, who is promoting hunting tours to Scotland, described how she had spent two days hunting goat before she fatally wounded one with a  yard shot using a long-range rle. She also posed with a stag which she killed on a stalking trip in the Highlands and told how she was looking forward to chefs cooking it at the castle where she was staying.Writing on her Instagram page, Switlyk said: Beautul wild goat here on the Island of Islay in Scotland. title: heavily pregnant womans nightmare night
story: NewsHeavily pregnant womans nightmare night as husband suffers heart attack hours before shes due to give birthA couple were preparing to go to the hospital for the birth of their first child when the unthinkable happenedShareByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAshley and Andrew were preparing for the birth of their first child when the unthinkable happened "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The birth of a child should be one of the happiest occasions of a persons le.But for two new parents from Saint Paul in Minnesota the day their child was born will be remembered for a rather dark reason.Ashley and Andrew Goette were preparing to go to the hospital so Ashleys labour could be induced.However just hours before they were due to leave for their appointment, the unthinkable happened and the mum-to-be awoke to find her husband suffering a heart attack.  While attempting not to panic for the sake of the baby, Ashley called emergency services who helped her perform CPR while they waited for an ambulance to arrive.However by the time paramedics reached Andrew, he was in full cardiac arrest and had been without oxygen for a y period, reports news.au.The ambulance team restarted the mans heart before taking him to hospital where he was placed in a medically induced coma in the intensive care unit. Ashley and other members of his family were told to prepare for the worst.  Doctors advised them that evenAndrew did come out of the coma, it was likely he would have a catastrophic brain injury. Not willing to leave her husbands side, Ashley decided to forgo her birth plans.I didnt want to have to think for one second about having to do any of this without him, she told Fox. I kept telling him the whole time he was asleep, or in his coma, that I was not going to have this baby until he woke up. And amazingly, thats just what happened. Andrew emerged from his coma, completely unscathed from any kind of brain damage and the following day his hospital bed was wheeled out of the ICU and parked beside his we while her labour was induced. But the complications didnt end there for the family. After several attempts to induce labour failed, doctors were forced to perform an emergency cesarean on Ashley.

story: NewsTerried fisherman surrounded by saltwater crocodiles in dead of night as their eyes light up in darkArash Tayebbi was fishing in Shady Camp billabong when he suddenly saw dozens of eyesShareCommentsByNelson GroomKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video terried-australian-fisherman-found-himself-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA fisherman found himself surrounded by saltwater crocodiles in the dead of night at a notoriously croc-infested waterway in Australia. Arash Tayebbi was fishing in Shady Camp billabong in the Northern Territory at am last Saturday when the predators hemmed him in on both sides. Eerie footage shows the eyes of the man-eaters glowing ominously as Arash aimed his flashlight back and forth on the banks of the billabong. Despite crocs previously lunging at the -year-old at the same spot, Arash said he did not feel his le was at risk - but actually found the encounter relaxing. He said: It was so dark I could only see them with the flashlight. There was loads of them on both sides of the barrage, up to .  But Im comfortable with that spot and nature generally relaxes me. If you love fishing you have to accept the risks, especially with how remote the Top End is. Shady Camp is one of the most densely populated crocodile destinations in the world and its been the site of a number of fatal attacks involving fisherman. In , -year-old Bill Scott was taken from his boat by a .mcrocodile while emptying a bucket over the side of his boat. Arash said he has nearly fallen victim to crocs at the same spot - but he isnt planning to stop wetting his line there anytime soon.  Arash said: Ive nearly been attacked by crocodiles in that spot three times before at night. Every time I kept a distance from the bank of three metres. As long as you dont have kids or pets with you, and you keep a keen eye, that should be enough to get away. Im used to that place and feel connected to all the animals there.

title: 8k fundraising bid to save dundee arcade legend champion the wonder horse
story: A fundraising campaign has been launched to keep Dundee icon Champion the Wonder Horse at home in the city.Adopted Dundonian Katherine Robison mounted the online appeal after we revealed Champion’s owner had put the ride-on horse up for sale.The fundraiser, hosted on the GoFundMe website, aims to raise the £, asking price and donate the arcade ride to Dundee Museum of Transport, where Champion is currently on display.Durham-born Katherine, who has lived in Dundee for  years, said her children Michael, , and one-year-old Yvain were “obsessed” with visiting Champion.The -year-old, from Stobswell, said: “I went to university here and met my husband Colin here – it is my adopted home.“For me it’s about keeping Champion as a reminder of old Dundee for new Dundonians.”Champion’s current owner Bill Adam bought the ride-on horse in .Bill, who grew up in Dundee’s Carolina House orphanage and spent much of his childhood visiting Champion at Shore Terrace arcade, said he hoped the fundraising campaign would succeed.He said the asking price would cover restoration costs and ensure that potential buyers were serious.“The fact is it has cost quite a bit to have him restored,” Bill added.“Even the money I’m asking for probably couldn’t cover the cost of replacing him.“The fact that Champion is still working and is in such good condition means his true worth far exceeds the asking price.“I absolutely want Champion to stay in Dundee and remain on show becauseI took him back he’d sit in the spare room.“As far as I’m concerned he should always be on display.”Dundee arcade legend Champion the Wonder Horse put up for sale" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-arcade-legend-champion-the-wonder-horse-put-up-for-sale embed # secretirjglDZ" data-secret"irjglDZ" width"" "" title"#Dundee arcade legend Champion the Wonder Horse put up for sale# # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: calls for area for scrambler bikers after youths cause havoc at camperdown park and nearby
story: Calls have been made for a designated area to be introduced for scrambler bikes in a bid to tackle antisocial behaviour.There have been reports of off-road bikers causing havoc at Camperdown Park.Dash cam footage shows three riders leaving a nature trail at the popular attraction.Problems with scrambler bikes have also been reported by residents in St Mary’s and at Clatto Woods.Captain James Crawford, chairman of trustees for the Friends of Camperdown House, has called for a solution to be found to please all parties.He said: “There were similar issues in Fe with scrambler bikes coming on to the land. An agreement was reached to allow them to use the space at certain times and that has gone some way to curbing the problems.“An area the size of Camperdown is very hard to police and we certainly don’t want people riding down nature trails in the park.“It would seem to be a sensible option to try to work with the riders to find a safe area for them to use.”Strathmartine councillor Stewart Hunter said he was happy to look at finding a solution to an “old problem”.He said: “In my time as a councillor there has always been a problem with scrambler bikes.“The police do all they can butthere was a place where the riders could go it would certainly make a lot of sense.“The problem is finding a suitable location that is safe and secluded.”Fellow area councillor Ian Borthwick said the latest incident was another example of “reckless” behaviour by those involved.He added: “I will certainly bring this latest incident to the attention of the authorities.“I’ve been made aware of issues in the park in the past.”Alan Ross, convener of the city council’s community safety and public protection committee, urged anyone who witnesses antisocial behaviour involving scrambler bikes to contact the police or the community safety wardens.He added: “This type of behaviour is completely unacceptable and is a blight on our communities.”

title: dundee education chiefs urged to withdraw from standardised tests scheme for pupils
story: Education chiefs in Dundee are being urged to consider withdrawing from a scheme of standardised tests being imposed on P pupils.Opposition councillors Fraser Macpherson and Craig Duncan want a vote on the future of Scottish National Standardised Assessmentsat Monday’s children and family services meeting.The controversial SNSAs have been publicly criticised by councils where in Scotland.Opponents say the tests could create league tables of primary schools.The Scottish Government’s Education Secretary John Swinney was defeated in a vote on the assessments by MSPs in September. However, he has so far refused to accept the outcome of the vote, which was non-binding.Should the Liberal Democrat councillors’ motion be passed, they have asked education chiefs to investigate whether the council can withdraw P pupils from the SNSAs and report back.

title: freeze the fees heres why 2100 people have supported our ninewells car parking campaign
story: More than , people have backed an Eveningcampaign calling for parking fees at Ninewells Hospital to be frozen. vw, px"  We launched Freeze the Fees earlier this month after Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd, which runs car parks at Ninewells on behalf of NHS Tayside as part of a -year contract, announced plans to increase its charges at the start of next month.The campaign received huge support – with , readers, including staff and patients at the hospital, along with politicians – signing a petition asking Indigo to keep parking charges at existing levels until at least next November.Having brought our petition to a close on Tuesday, we will now submit the results to Indigo in the hope that the firm, which is based in Watford, will perform a U-turn on its plans.Many of our readers gave us their reasons for signing the petition – the vast majority insisting parking should be free of charge, but many also hitting out at the proposed rise.Charges are due to rise from £. to £. for a single visit – with staff permits also going up.Donna Hutton said: “The charges rise frequently, causing an extra financial burden on staff and families of long-term patients.”Paula Brand, who works as a nurse at Ninewells, said: “Anything to be done in our favour is worth backing. Indigo not only continue to raise the prices of parking, they also limit the payment method to coins only.“No card payments notes which can cause staff to be late on sht trying to get change from shops or being stuck in the car park due to no shops being open after a late sht .”Vicky Cameron added: “Fees are high enough. Lots of people struggle to pay them.“Hitting people in the pocket at the worst time possible.”Aimee Venables said: “You shouldn’t be charged for parking at a hospital full stop.“These p price increases happen knowing people don’t have that random amount of change and end up paying more as the machine doesn’t give change back.”Heather Rice added: “I work at Ninewells and think we pay enough to park there.”Fellow staff member Louise McIntosh said: “I work as a nurse at Ninewells and think the increase is unfair and unnecessary.”Danielle Dodds added: “We shouldn’t need to pay for visiting our hospital anyway, never mind putting the fees up.”Liberal Democrat councillor Fraser Macpherson, whose West End ward includes the hospital, signed the petition and said: “The proposed car parking charges increases cannot be justied.”Indigo has only made one public statement on the proposed increase, saying that the fees are reviewed every year in line with the retail price index, as per its contract with NHS Tayside.However, it has declined to provide a full explanation for the reasons behind this increase – the third since .The health board says the parking firm has control over the fees, but any proposed increases are reviewed by NHS bosses before being approved.The Scottish Government has rejected repeated calls for fees at the hospital to be scrapped altogether, saying that it would come at a huge cost to the public purse – meaning people will continue to be charged to park at Ninewells until at least , when the current contract runs out.Ninewells is one of only three hospitals in the country to charge visitors and staff to use its car parks.

title: george cran roles reversed as pressure now on dunfermline and allan johnston as dundee united look to gather momentum
story: With the first quarter of the season behind them, it’s fair to say it’s been a bumpy ride so far for Dundee United.Often coaches will use this point of the campaign as the first real chance to assess how things are going as they prepare to meet sides for the second time in the league.For the Tangerines, though, a report card right now can’t possibly tell the whole story with Csaba Laszlo not even lasting to this marker in charge of the team.And to judge his replacement Robbie Neilson after just two matches in charge wouldn’t be fair.However, comparing the fortunes of their next opponents Dunfermline since they met on the opening league match of the season makes for interesting reading.That’s because the atmosphere around Allan Johnston’s Pars since they finally overturned a -match winless run against the Tangerines to continue a lightning-fast start to the campaign has flipped almost completely.While the Tangerines struggled and stumbled under Csaba’s reign at the start of the season, Johnston was enjoying seeing his side inflict a - win at Tannadice to make it five wins from five games played after a % record in their Betfred Cup group.That was with an impressive  goals scored and included a deserved - win at Premiership Dundee.Now, though, Johnston faces a new man in the other dugout with intense scrutiny from fans now on him rather than his opposite number.After their perfect start to the campaign, it took Dunfermline another five matches to register a second victory in the Championship and have only racked up eight points from eight matches since.In the process they only managed six goals, conceding  and being dumped out of both the League Cup and Irn-Bru Cup on penalty shoot-outs.Going into Saturday’s game at East End Park, the Pars sit adrt of the play-off places, four points behind United in fourth place.Another poor result, after their - home defeat to Queen of the South at the weekend, will leave them well behind in the race for the top four, heaping all the pressure on Johnston and his side.And the contrast with Neilson, his United players and the atmosphere among the support is stark.After kicking off his reign with a - victory at Partick Thistle, the new gaffer led the Tangerines out for the first time at Tannadice at the weekend.Despite not managing to make it two wins from two, drawing - with Inverness CT, the players were boosted by the biggest home crowd of the campaign.The belief that Neilson can repeat the feat of promotion to the Premiership he achieved at Hearts is clear among the United support.Optimism throughout the stands has been almost completely absent over the past couple of seasons but the hope is now with former chairman Stephen Thompson having departed, and Neilson taking the reigns, good times might be on the horizon.And the ideal time to fuel that fire is now with games against sides below them in the table coming up – Dunfermline this weekend and then Queens the week after.With both the sides coming up in indferent form, points are a must to keep the good feeling flowing.Because what Dunfermline did show the last time the teams met, despite what’s happened since, is they can actually beat their bogey side United.What Neilson can’t afford now is to let the early momentum slip away, something that happened with both Ray McKinnon and, more obviously, Csaba Laszlo.Preventing that could well show the fans’ early optimism is justied come the season end.

title: green spaces and river tay cited as perth becomes only city to oppose car ban
story: Perth is the only city in Scotland where most residents oppose car bans, a new poll reveals.There is widespread support for vehicle-free measures in city centres across the country, according to a Panelbase survey.But more than half oppose the embargoes in Perth, which is home to one of the most polluted streets in the country.Andrew Llanwarne, from Friends of the Earth Tayside, said low support for car bans in Perth could be linked with a lack of awareness of the impact of pollution.“Maybe in Perth, many people are lulled into a  sense of security by the proximity of the River Tay and the green spaces of the two Inches,” he said.The poll found % of Scots are in favour of car-free measures, % are against and % did not express an opinion.In Perth, % said they are a good idea, with % against and the rest not taking a position.

title: jim mcintyre expected to make first dundee signing ahead of celtic clash
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre is swtly set to bolster his options by adding free agent Martin Woods to his squad.The former Ross County midfielder has been without a club since leaving Partick Thistle after their relegation last season and is set to be re-united with his former gaffer.McIntyre signed Woods twice while gaffer in Dingwall, the first a month after taking charge before the -year-old had a spell down south with Shrewsbury before ing north.Woods has been training with the Dark Blues since last week and was present at last night’s - defeat to Hearts.He’s expected to become the manager’s first signing before next week’s home clash with Celtic.Woods was previously linked Dens back in the summer but the move never materialised under the reigns of then-manager Neil McCann.
